column1: Genes work together in context-specific networks to karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding ekspression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous studies have described different regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

column6:
[PASS] (1.00)

Genes function within context-specific networks to carry out various biological processes, and variations in these genes can impact disease-relevant pathways. Understanding how genes influence complex traits requires a mechanistic understanding of gene expression regulation across different cell types, which is crucial for developing improved treatments. Previous studies have described different regulatory DNA elements and genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data has improved the identification of transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology. However, there is still a need to better understand the specific gene expression patterns that underlie disease etiology and drug mechanisms. This manuscript aims to address this gap by projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns, highlighting the potential for identifying therapeutic targets and drug repurposing opportunities. The novel approach used in this study will provide insights into the clustering of complex traits and contribute to a deeper understanding of disease etiology and drug mechanisms, ultimately advancing the field of genetic studies and functional genomics.

---
Genes work together in context-specific networks to carry out different functions, and variations in these genes can change their functional role and affect disease-relevant biological processes. However, determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding expression regulation across different cell types, which in turn should lead to improved treatments. Previous studies have described different regulatory DNA elements, including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data has improved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology. Despite these advancements, there is still a need for a method that can effectively project genetic associations through gene expression patterns to highlight disease etiology and drug mechanisms. This manuscript aims to fill this gap by presenting a novel approach that utilizes gene co-expression and clustering of complex traits to identify therapeutic targets and potential drug repurposing opportunities. The results of this study provide insights into disease etiology and drug mechanisms, ultimately contributing to the broader field of genetic studies and functional genomics.

---
Genes work together in context-specific networks to carry out different functions, and variations in these genes can change their functional role and affect disease-relevant biological processes. However, determining how genes influence complex traits requires a mechanistic understanding of expression regulation across different cell types, which is crucial for developing improved treatments. Previous studies have described different regulatory DNA elements, including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data has improved the identification of transcriptional mechanisms that commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology when dysregulated. Despite these advancements, there is still a need to project genetic associations through gene expression patterns to highlight disease etiology and drug mechanisms. This manuscript aims to fill this gap by presenting a novel method that utilizes gene co-expression and clustering of complex traits to identify therapeutic targets and potential drug repurposing opportunities. The results of this study will provide insights into disease etiology and drug mechanisms, ultimately advancing the field of genetic studies and functional genomics.
